p: Seasonal viruses are responsible for hundreds of thousands of deaths and extensive morbidity in temperate climates each year [ 1, 2]. In the United States, epidemics of respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) and influenza typically begin in the Southeast United States and progress to the Northwest, through the months of October to April [ 3, 4, 5]. Much of the seasonal timing and geographic spread between respiratory viruses coincide, resulting in high prevalence of coinfection globally, which may potentially be linked to disease severity [ 6, 7, 8].
